headline: Republicans react to Donald Trump’s endorsement of Dr. Oz
author: Dennis Owens

Seven candidates are currently in the Republican primary race, including Trump’s former Danish ambassador Carla Sands, Fox News contributor Kathy Barnette, and former Lt.
McCormick interviewed with Trump in 2016 for a possible position in his administration and has been endorsed by Parnell and former Trump Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.
Many conservatives have blasted Trump’s decision as ads play across Pennsylvania calling the former television show host Oz a “RHINO” – Republican In Name Only.
(WHTM) – Former President Donald Trump sent shockwaves across Pennsylvania when he formally endorsed Dr. Mehmet Oz in Pennsylvania’s crowded U.S. Senate race.
In a WHTM/Emerson College Polling/The Hill poll released in March, 61% of Pennsylvania Republican voters said they would vote for a Trump-endorsed candidate.
“If that’s the biggest criticism against me, I’m in good shape,” Oz told abc27’s Dennis Owens during a March campaign visit to a Harrisburg diner.
“I believe that Mehmet Oz will be the one most able to win the General Election against a Radical Left Democrat,” said Trump on Saturday.
“I don’t think the President is getting very good advice,” said Senate candidate Carla Sands, who served as Trump’s Danish ambassador.
A criticism brought against Oz by campaign opponents has been his residency, with people questioning whether he’s from Pennsylvania.
More than 25% said an endorsement would make no difference and 13.2% said it would make them less likely to support a candidate.
The 61-year-old also holds dual citizenship with Turkey but has vowed to renounce it should he be elected to the Senate.
Lowman Henry of the PA Leadership Conference says Trump’s decision to endorse Oz has left many scratching their heads.
“I am honored to receive President Trump’s full support and endorsement, and I thank him for that,” said Oz.

Trump has not yet endorsed a candidate in the race for Governor in Pennsylvania.
Nearly 33% of voters said they were undecided in the Republican Senate race.
Pennsylvania’s primary election will be held on May 17.
“I’m very proud that I’m a Pennsylvanian,” said Oz.
